review: I was given these from the hospital for a severe kidney infection. The dosage was two 500mg for 5 days. Worst tablets I've ever been on, they made me want to self detonate. They have even gave me Jaundice which is a 1 in 1000 chance. They were very fast acting towards the kidney and kidney pain which is good but side effects were very very nasty.Side effects I experienced: - severe nausea - dry mouth - vomiting - dizziness - abdominal pain -headache - muscle aches- confusion - extreme fatigue - fever and cold sweats - jaundice (yellowing of skin, eyes and urine) I've been off the tablets for about 48 hours now (thank God) but now need time be treated for jaundice. Only good thing I can say about these is that they are very fast acting. I wouldn't recommend these at all even if you are desperate please ask for something else.

Currently on day 4 of 7 of my Ciprofloxacin regiment for a kidney infection. I haven't had a nightmare of an experience by any means but this is definitely one nasty drug. Within 20 mins of ingesting, I experience quite intense abdominal cramping on my left and it's worse than my kidney pain. This lasts about 30min-1 hour until my muscles relax again so I take an Advil in preparation for it which helps. I've also been experiencing heavy night sweats. It's a little hard to determine what is the result of my infection and what is a side effect of the medication but I'm quite confident about these two in particular. I take the pill with about 500ml-1L of water. Food doesn't seem to make much of a difference for me. The restrictions for dairy also make the morning scheduling super annoying as yogurt and granola is my go to. All that said, my kidney infection pain is all but gone now and I feel like I'm on the road to recovery so it is effective; it's just a pain the way it goes about it.

I would strongly caution you about taking this drug for anything. While it is widely prescribed, the side effects are not obvious on the leaflet you get from the pharmacy. I spoke to gps, a nurse, and a pharmacist and they didn’t know about the risks of the drug induced neuropathy I started experiencing after taking just two pills. I was experiencing pins and needles, numbness in my leg and foot. It was scary and I am a 31 year old female who has never had a reaction to antibiotics except a small rash. The FDA warns this is side effect is 50% more likely with this class of drugs! There are so many other options of antibiotics out there. At the first sign of trouble, I stopped this drug immediately and took bromelain, magnesium, b6 and was switched to amoxicillin. The side effects started to regress two days after stopping. Please be careful!

Cipro (ciprofloxacin):Went to the doc with the typical symptoms of kidney infection.  While my UA was clear, the doc Rx'ed Cipro.  I'd had a bad reaction in the past (depression) but decided to try again since I was desperate for relief.  This time it hit me completely different--more of a mood lift than anything.  I recall Levaquin making me feel almost hypomanic like this too, which I didn't mind.  More importantly, the infection seems to be improving.  Make sure to read the package insert & follow the dosing instructions carefully.  Take with food & a large glass of water (or two).  Avoid caffeine in any form, calcium/magnesium supplements & sunlight as well as NSAIDs.  If you're worried about tendon rupture, avoid exercise.  Most people don't bother reading the dosing instructions or think they don't apply to them then wonder why the med made them sick.  Obviously fluoroquinolones are heavy duty meds that can cause damage but that goes for many things in life.  Risk vs. benefit.
